acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Based on its 96-hour LC50 of 1.9mg/L for fish (rainbow trout) (Initial Risk Assessment Report (NITE, CERI, NEDO), 2005), the substance was classified into Category 2.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Since the rabbit LD50 = 1500mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)), the substance was classified into Category 4.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Although rat LC50 of 0.011mg/L was documented (PATTY (5th, 2001) vol. 9), exposure periods were not provided. Thus, classification is not possible.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Since the rat LD50 = 261mg/kg (EHC No. 93 (1989)), the substance was classified into Category 3. For toxicity of other isomers, refer to classifications of 2-chlorophenol and 3-chlorophenol.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its classification for acute toxicity is Category 2 and it is not rapidly degradable (non-biodegradable, BOD degradability: 2% (Biodegradation and Bioconcentration of Existing Chemical Substances under the Chemical Substances Control Law, 1979)), the substance was classified into Category 2.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification is not possible due to lack of in vivo data. Among in vitro mutagenicity tests conducted, both positive and negative results have been documented from Ames tests (ATSDR (1999), NTP DB (accessed June 2008)).

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure in the molecule

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing chlorine and oxygen, with these elements chemically bonded only to carbon.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Mild hyperemia was observed at 0.6mg/kg, severe hyperemia was observed at 1.2mg/kg, and severe hyperemia with edematous swelling,corneal cloudiness,and exudation were observed (ATSDR (1999)). Its classification for skin corrosion is Category 1.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Since the substance was corrosive in topical application tests using rabbits (ATSDR (1999)), it was classified into Category 1.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In 28-day repeated oral administration tests using rats (GLP-compliant), increased leukocytes were observed in males treated at 500mg/kg (90-day conversion: 166mg/kg/day) in hematological studies; and no effects of the substance were observed on body weight, on food consumption, in blood chemistry studies, in autopsy, on organ weight, and in histopathological studies. These changes seen during the periods of administration were recoverable (Toxicity Testing Reports of Environmental Chemicals (Chemicals Investigation Promoting Council) (accessed June 2008)). Since the doses used in these oral studies exceed Category 2 guidance values, classification into "Not classified" is applicable. However, because no data on other administration routes were available, classification is not possible.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: It was observed that oral administration tests caused restlessness, motor weakness, tremors, convulsion, or central nervous system depression, etc, in rats and mice (ATSDR (1999)). However, because doses tested were unknown and other details were not available, classification is not possible.
